item.title: Woman charged after man shot at apartment complex in Greenville - Darkhorse Press
item.author: Morgan Howard
item.description:
GREENVILLE – A Greenville woman has been charged after police said a man was shot during a domestic dispute Tuesday at Riverwalk Apartments.

Officers with the Greenville Police Department responded Feb. 17 to a report of a shooting at 738 W. Union St., police said. When officers arrived, they made contact with a female inside the residence, who told them a male victim was in the bathroom with a gunshot wound.

The victim was transported to Delta Health System for treatment. Police said additional details about the circumstances surrounding the shooting remain under investigation.

Investigators charged 28-year-old Larineisha Askew of Greenville with one count of domestic aggravated assault. She is awaiting her initial appearance, police said.

All suspects are presumed innocent unless proven guilty.

item.title: Two arrested, third wanted in Pearl River County drive-by shooting investigation - Darkhorse Press
item.author: Morgan Howard
item.description:
PEARL RIVER COUNTY – Two people have been arrested and a third is being sought in connection with a drive-by shooting investigation in Pearl River County, according to the Pearl River County Sheriff’s Office.

Deputies responded Feb. 9, 2026, to Highland Hospital after a male victim arrived with a gunshot wound, authorities said. Investigators later determined the shooting occurred near the intersection of Mississippi Highway 53 and Barth Road in Poplarville.

The sheriff’s office said the suspected gunman was identified as Austyn Reynolds, and investigators also identified a Nissan Altima as the suspected vehicle involved.

Authorities said Michelle Rogers was identified as an accomplice who allegedly helped Reynolds attempt to evade law enforcement after the shooting.

In a coordinated effort between the Pearl River County Sheriff’s Office and the Bogalusa Police Department, Reynolds and Rogers were taken into custody without incident, the sheriff’s office said.

Investigators later determined that Shyanne Thibodeaux also assisted Reynolds and Rogers in evading law enforcement after the shooting, authorities said. An arrest warrant remains outstanding for Thibodeaux, the sheriff’s office said.

Reynolds was arrested and charged with drive-by shooting under Mississippi Code Section 97-3-109(1). Rogers was charged with accessory after the fact to drive-by shooting under Mississippi Code Section 97-1-5(1)(a)(i), authorities said. Thibodeaux faces an outstanding warrant for accessory after the fact to drive-by shooting under the same statute, officials said.

Sheriff David Allison thanked the Bogalusa Police Department and the Hancock County Sheriff’s Office for assisting in the investigation and said deputies and investigators worked to resolve what he described as a violent crime.

item.title: Tate County Sheriff’s Office K-9s Soul and Stuccie receive donated body armor - Darkhorse Press
item.author: Morgan Howard
item.description:
SENATOBIA — The Tate County Sheriff’s Office said its K-9s, Soul and Stuccie, have received new bullet- and stab-protective vests through a donation arranged by the nonprofit Vested Interest in K9s Inc.

The sheriff’s office said the vests were sponsored by Don and Misty Fike of Galesburg, Illinois, and embroidered with the message: “Born to Love- Trained to Serve-Loyal Always.”

Vested Interest in K9s Inc., founded in 2009, is a 501(c)(3) organization that provides protective vests and other assistance to law enforcement K-9s nationwide. The group said the vests are U.S.-made, custom-fitted and certified to National Institute of Justice standards.

Since its founding, the nonprofit said it has provided more than 6,225 vests valued at about $6.9 million to K-9s in all 50 states through private and corporate donations.

The organization said its program is open to U.S. law enforcement dogs that are at least 20 months old and actively employed and certified, and K-9s with expired vests may also be eligible.

item.title: Study: Absolutely nobody checked on 12,659 Mississippi seniors in January - Darkhorse Press
item.author: Therese Apel
item.description:
JACKSON — Nearly one-third of Mississippi seniors who live alone went the entire month of January without a single meaningful check-in, underscoring concerns about what health officials have called a growing loneliness epidemic in America.

A new survey by Choice Mutual found that 32% of Mississippi residents age 65 and older who live alone reported no one had checked on them since Jan. 1. That equates to an estimated 12,659 seniors statewide who experienced a full month without meaningful social contact.

The findings come as national health experts warn that chronic loneliness can carry health risks comparable to smoking heavily. U.S. leaders, including the former U.S. surgeon general, have described social isolation as a public health crisis, particularly among older Americans.

Choice Mutual surveyed 3,025 seniors nationwide at the end of January, asking a single question: “Has anyone checked in on you since January 1?”

Overall, 26% said no, and Mississippi’s rate exceeded the national average.

The survey identified the five states with the highest share of seniors living alone who reported zero check-ins in January: Wyoming and Oklahoma at 50%, followed by Louisiana at 44%, and Arizona and Connecticut at 42%.

Beyond the headline number, the survey painted a broader picture of winter isolation.

Among seniors living alone nationwide:

The emotional toll appears to run deep. Sixty-eight percent said they feel forgotten or invisible during the winter. Nearly three in 10, or 29%, said they do not have even one person they can confide in during difficult times.

More than half, 58%, said they worry their loneliness is harming their health, and 62% reported that isolation affected their physical or mental health this winter.

Even seniors who do not live alone are not immune. The survey found that 65% of older adults who live with a partner still sometimes feel alone.

Anthony Martin, founder of Choice Mutual , said the results should be viewed as a warning.

“Loneliness is often dismissed as a soft issue, but the numbers show it’s anything but,” Martin said. “When a quarter of seniors go a full month without a check-in, that’s not just a social concern — it’s a public-health warning light.”

He said many seniors are not seeking major interventions, but simple connection.

“In many cases, a simple phone call or knock on the door would make a meaningful difference,” Martin said.

The survey also highlighted how difficult it can be for seniors to break the cycle of isolation. While 28% said they are very likely to reach out when feeling lonely, 40% said they are unlikely or very unlikely to do so.

Still, 64% said their well-being would improve if someone reached out more often.

As winter continues and social isolation remains a concern nationwide, advocates say small acts of connection — a call, a visit or a check-in — may be among the most powerful tools to combat what many now consider one of the country’s most overlooked health threats.

item.title: Street sweeper driver killed in collision with 18-wheeler in Lowndes County - Darkhorse Press
item.author: Morgan Howard
item.description:
LOWNDES COUNTY — The driver of a street sweeper was killed Wednesday afternoon in a crash involving an 18-wheeler on Industrial Park Road, according to the Lowndes County Sheriff’s Office.

Deputies responded to the crash at about 3 p.m. Feb. 18, 2026. A preliminary investigation indicates the street sweeper driver was fatally injured in the collision, authorities said.

The sheriff’s office said the 18-wheeler driver was not reported to have suffered life-threatening injuries.

Emergency responders and investigators remained at the scene for several hours while the crash was investigated and the roadway was cleared. Traffic on Industrial Park Road was temporarily affected.

The identity of the person killed is being withheld pending notification of next of kin.

The crash remains under investigation. Anyone with information is asked to contact the Lowndes County Sheriff’s Office.

“Our thoughts and prayers are with the victim’s family during this difficult time,” Sheriff Eddie Hawkins said in a statement. “We ask motorists to remain cautious and attentive, especially around commercial and maintenance vehicles operating on our roadways.”

item.title: Sheriff: No more deputies standing in roadway for Shannon school traffic control - Darkhorse Press
item.author: Morgan Howard
item.description:
LEE COUNTY — The Lee County Sheriff’s Office said it will no longer place deputies in the middle of a highway to direct school traffic at Shannon Primary and Shannon Elementary schools, citing safety concerns.

In a statement, Sheriff Jim H. Johnson said the change is effective immediately and follows what he described as the recent loss of two school resource officers and another close call Monday morning.

Lee County deputy killed after being struck by vehicle near Shannon School

Johnson said the sheriff’s office is meeting with the school district superintendent and staff, along with representatives from the Mississippi Department of Transportation, to evaluate safer traffic options.

The sheriff said agencies are working together to implement changes aimed at improving traffic flow while protecting deputies, students, staff and families.

Johnson urged parents and guardians to allow extra time for student drop-off and pick-up as the changes are developed and put in place.

item.title: Officer, prisoner killed in I-10 crash involving transport van in Jackson County - Darkhorse Press
item.author: Morgan Howard
item.description:
JACKSON COUNTY – A prisoner and a transport officer were killed and three other people were seriously injured Wednesday morning when a private prisoner transport van crashed on Interstate 10 in Jackson County, according to WLOX.

WLOX reported the crash happened around 9:30 a.m. in the westbound lanes of I-10 near the Ocean Springs Exit 50 ramp to Mississippi Highway 609. The van struck a pole, overturned and collided with a utility truck.

The Mississippi Highway Patrol said there were four people inside the transport van and one person in the utility truck. Two people in the van, an officer and a prisoner, died, and the other two occupants in the van were critically injured, WLOX reported.

The utility truck driver was taken to a local hospital in stable condition.

WLOX reported a medical helicopter was called to transport one of the most critically injured victims. After the crash, the van caught fire, and the Jackson County Sheriff’s Office arrived first and put out the fire, according to the station. Jackson County Fire then cut into the van to rescue those inside.

The transport van was operated by St. Joseph Services, a private prisoner transport company, WLOX reported. The station said the trip began Tuesday night and involved prisoners picked up in Florida, with planned destinations including Ocean City, New Jersey, and Spaulding, Georgia. The van was also in Mississippi to pick up an inmate from the Harrison County Adult Detention Center when it crashed, according to the report.

Multiple agencies responded and a crash reconstruction was conducted. The cause of the crash had not been released as of Wednesday, WLOX reported.

item.title: Meridian Police Department makes first arrest under Mississippi grooming statute - Darkhorse Press
item.author: Cash Matlock
item.description:
MERIDIAN – The Meridian Police Department has made its first arrest under Mississippi’s Grooming of a Child statute, marking what officials described as a significant milestone for the department.

Dennis Palmer was arrested Feb. 18 with assistance from the Lauderdale County Sheriff’s Department and the East Mississippi Drug Task Force. He was wanted on charges of Grooming of a Child under Mississippi State Code § 97-5-32 and Procurement of Sexual Servitude of a Minor under Mississippi State Code § 97-3-54.

The Grooming of a Child statute was enacted in July 2025 by the state of Mississippi. Authorities said this is the first arrest made by the Meridian Police Department under the new law.

Bond was set at $1 million, according to the department.

The case was investigated by the Meridian Police Department’s Human Trafficking/ICAC Unit, with assistance from the department’s Gang Unit, SWAT Team and K-9 Unit.

Officials said the arrest underscores the department’s ongoing efforts to protect children and hold accountable those accused of exploiting minors. The department said it will continue working with law enforcement partners to pursue similar cases in the future.

Palmer is presumed innocent unless and until proven guilty in a court of law.

item.title: Man Found Shot to Death in Vacant Skyline Drive Home - Darkhorse Press
item.author: Therese Apel
item.description:
JACKSON — A man believed to have been reported missing earlier in the day was found shot to death Tuesday night inside a vacant residence in the 3600 block of Skyline Drive, authorities said.

Interim Police Chief and Hinds County Sheriff Tyree Jones said officers responded shortly after 9 p.m. after receiving information that a missing person might be at or near the location. Upon arrival, officers found a Black male deceased inside the vacant property.

“It’s apparent that he had been shot at least once,” Jones said during a press conference at the scene.

The killing marks Jackson’s eighth homicide of the year.

Authorities believe the victim may be the same individual reported missing earlier Tuesday in Jackson. However, Jones said investigators are awaiting formal identification and family notification before releasing the name. The victim is believed to be in his early 30s.

Investigators also reported that a 2020 gray Nissan Sentra belonging to the victim is missing from the scene.

Jones said officers were alerted to the area based on information that the missing person could be nearby. Family members of the missing individual were also in the area and spoke with officers, leading to the discovery of the body inside the vacant home.

Police do not believe the victim lived at the residence and said the property is unoccupied. Investigators are working to determine why the victim was at the location and what connection, if any, exists between him and the property.

Authorities have not identified a motive and said the case remains under investigation.

Anyone with information is asked to contact the Jackson Police Department.

item.title: Jackson Police Seek Suspect in Two Burglaries at Hometown BBQ - Darkhorse Press
item.author: Therese Apel
item.description:
JACKSON — Jackson Police Department is asking for the public’s help identifying a suspect linked to two burglaries at a local restaurant earlier this month.

Police said Hometown BBQ, located at 3152 Medgar Evers Blvd., was first burglarized Feb. 2. The business was targeted again on Feb. 14.

According to investigators, surveillance footage indicates the same individual may be responsible for both break-ins.

Authorities released video from the incidents and said the investigation remains ongoing.

Anyone with information is urged to contact the Jackson Police Department at 601-960-1234 or Crime Stoppers at 601-355-TIPS (8477).

item.title: Cybersecurity attack forces UMMC to close statewide clinics, cancel outpatient procedures - Darkhorse Press
item.author: Morgan Howard
item.description:
JACKSON – The University of Mississippi Medical Center said Thursday that a cybersecurity attack has taken many of its information technology systems offline, including access to its electronic medical records system, Epic.

In a public notice dated Feb. 19, UMMC said all of its clinic locations statewide are closed for the day.

UMMC said outpatient and ambulatory surgeries and procedures, along with imaging appointments, have been canceled and will be rescheduled.

Hospital services are continuing using downtime procedures, the medical center said.

UMMC said it will provide additional updates as more information becomes available and apologized for the disruption.

item.title: Crime Stoppers, Tupelo police seek public’s help identifying suspects in Walmart jewelry theft - Darkhorse Press
item.author: Morgan Howard
item.description:
TUPELO – Crime Stoppers of Northeast Mississippi and the Tupelo Police Department are asking for the public’s help identifying a suspect in a false pretense case involving the theft of jewelry from a Tupelo Walmart.

According to investigators, the incident occurred Feb. 11, 2026, at about 1:25 p.m. at Walmart, 2270 W. Main St. Police said two unknown men entered the store and went to the jewelry section, where they concealed multiple jewelry items.

Authorities said the suspects then left the store without paying. The total value of the stolen merchandise exceeded $5,000, according to Crime Stoppers.

Anyone with information is asked to call Crime Stoppers of Northeast Mississippi at 800-773-TIPS (8477) or submit an anonymous tip through the P3 Tips app. Crime Stoppers said tips that lead to an arrest could be eligible for a cash reward of up to $2,000.

item.title: Cheshire Abbey Rescues Dogs Surrendered During Raid at Jackson Home - Darkhorse Press
item.author: Morgan Howard
item.description:
JACKSON – An animal rescue group called Cheshire Abbey said four dogs were surrendered to its care after local and federal law enforcement conducted a raid at a home in Jackson’s Fondren area earlier today.

Cheshire Abbey Animal Rescue said in a social media post that responders found four large dogs chained in the front of the home. The group alleged the chains were too short and too heavy, and that the dogs did not have proper shelter or water. The rescue also said the animals did not have required rabies vaccinations.

Rather than face potential citations, the people at the home relinquished the animals.

Cheshire Abbey said it is currently at capacity following recent cold-weather rescues and plans to board the dogs while they are assessed. The rescue said it evaluates animals before adoption and does not place aggressive dogs.

The group praised law enforcement partners involved in the response and asked the community for donations to help cover boarding and veterinary costs.

You can donate to their care on the rescue’s Facebook post by clicking below.

These rescues cannot do this by themselves. It takes a village to help the forgotten dogs discarded in Mississippi every single day. It is exhausting for a small group to do alone…so whether you skip your daily $5 coffee and donate, that or reach out and offer to foster, we challenge you to do something.

It can be something big or small…but please do something.

item.title: Woman charged after domestic stabbing in Lamar County - Darkhorse Press
item.author: Morgan Howard
item.description:
LAMAR COUNTY – A 48-year-old woman has been charged with aggravated assault in a domestic violence case after deputies said a man was stabbed during a fight Monday night at an apartment on Shears Road.

Deputies responded around 9 p.m. Feb. 16, 2026, after a reported stabbing, according to authorities. Investigators said a 38-year-old man suffered a stab wound to the abdomen and was transported by ambulance to a local hospital, where he underwent surgery.

item.title: Tupelo man sentenced to 25 years after guilty plea in 2023 killing - Darkhorse Press
item.author: Morgan Howard
item.description:
TUPELO – A man has been sentenced to 25 years in prison after pleading guilty to second-degree murder in the 2023 death of Montavious Jemar Clifton, according to the First Circuit District Attorney’s Office.

Circuit Court Judge John R. White sentenced Hatchett to 25 years in the custody of the Mississippi Department of Corrections, the district attorney’s office said. Prosecutors said Hatchett will be required to serve the full 25-year term and will not be eligible for parole or early release.

The district attorney’s office said an additional 15 years were suspended, and Hatchett will be required to complete five years of post-release supervision after he is released from prison.

The case was investigated by the Tupelo Police Department. Assistant District Attorney Sadie Gardner prosecuted the case.

item.title: Teen Charged With Capital Murder in Fatal Grove Circle Shooting - Darkhorse Press
item.author: Therese Apel
item.description:
UPDATE: On Wednesday, Javeon Wilson appeared before a Municipal Court Judge and received a $250K bond for the charge of Aggravated Assault and no bond for the Capital Murder charge.

JACKSON — A 17-year-old has been arrested and charged with capital murder in connection with a February shooting at a Jackson apartment complex that left one man dead and another injured, police said.

Jackson Police Department officials announced that Javeon Wilson, 17, has been taken into custody by the department’s Robbery/Homicide Unit. Wilson is charged with capital murder and aggravated assault in the death of Glen Blackwell III and the wounding of a second victim.

Wilson was booked into city holding and is awaiting his initial court appearance.

The shooting occurred Feb. 12 at an apartment complex on Grove Circle near North State Street. Precinct 4 officers responded to reports that several people had been shot. Robbery/Homicide detectives were called to the scene.

Investigators determined that two individuals were injured during the incident and were transported by ambulance to local hospitals. Hospital staff later informed detectives that one of the victims, Glen Blackwell III, died from his injuries. The second victim was treated for non-life-threatening injuries.

Police said the suspects were initially described as five to six unknown males wearing masks who fled the scene on foot. At the time of the initial release, no arrests had been made.

Authorities said the motive for the shooting appeared to be robbery. The investigation remains active.

Anyone with information is asked to contact the Jackson Police Department at 601-960-1234 or Crime Stoppers at 601-355-TIPS (8477).

item.title: Starkville Derby dachshund race set for record turnout April 25 - Darkhorse Press
item.author: Therese Apel
item.description:
STARKVILLE — The fourth annual Starkville Derby, billed as the world’s largest dachshund race, is expected to draw more than 250 racing dogs from over 20 states and crowds in the tens of thousands when it returns April 25.

Organizers of the Starkville Derby say this year’s event will be its largest yet, with competitors traveling from as far away as Rhode Island and Washington state. Past champions have come from outside Mississippi, including winners from Georgia in 2023 and 2024 and a Texas dog named Forest last year.

In addition to the races, the Derby features the Boardtown Pizza and Pints Arts Festival, with nearly 200 approved food and art vendors. Other attractions include live music, a children’s zone, flyovers, the Old Dominick Call to Post, Mutt Juleps and an appearance by the Oscar Mayer Wienermobile.

“We are so excited to welcome even more of our friends to the next edition of the world’s largest wiener dog race,” said Alden Thornhill, founder and host of the event. “Our team can’t wait to welcome so many new folks, both two- and four-legged, to the greatest show on turf on April 25th.”

The Derby has received multiple statewide and regional honors, including recognition from the Mississippi Tourism Association as Best Large Festival, the Mississippi Main Street Association as Best Creative Large Event and designation as a Top 20 Signature Event by the Southeast Tourism Society.

Founded in 2023 by a group of friends seeking to create a spring festival in Starkville, the event supports the Oktibbeha County Humane Society and has raised more than $150,000 for shelter pets, according to organizers.

The multi-camera HD broadcast of the races will begin at 11 a.m. CDT on the event’s YouTube channel and Facebook page. Organizers say the festival has generated millions of social media impressions while becoming one of Mississippi’s largest arts festivals.

More information is available at thestarkvillederby.com.

item.title: Southern Pines Waives, Reduces Dog Adoption Fees During Weekend Event - Darkhorse Press
item.author: Therese Apel
item.description:
HATTIESBURG — Adoption fees for dogs and puppies will be waived or reduced this weekend at Southern Pines Animal Shelter as the shelter works to place dozens of animals in permanent homes.

The fee promotion runs Thursday through Sunday at three locations in Hattiesburg, making it “easier and more affordable than ever” for families to adopt, shelter officials said.

“It may be surprising, but January is one of our busiest puppy seasons in Hattiesburg,” said Amanda Paris, shelter director. “Our shelter is full of adorable puppies and adult dogs of all shapes, sizes and personalities, and they’re just waiting for you.”

Adoptable dogs and puppies will be available with reduced or waived fees at the shelter, 1901 N. 31st Ave., from noon to 5 p.m. Thursday through Sunday. Additional adoption events will be held Saturday and Sunday from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. at PetSmart in Hattiesburg, and Sunday from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. at Petco in Hattiesburg.

Saturday’s event at PetSmart coincides with “Adopt Joy,” a partnership with PetSmart Charities aimed at connecting families with pets. Shelter officials said research shows pet ownership can benefit cognitive, physical and emotional wellness and help children learn values such as patience and compassion.

All adoptions include age-appropriate vaccinations, spay or neuter surgery, a microchip, 30 days of pet health insurance and a sample bag of food. The shelter said the reduced fees cover those services.

Founded in 1952, Southern Pines operates a no-kill shelter that cares for more than 4,000 lost and unwanted dogs and cats each year. The organization also runs a transport program, thrift shops in Hattiesburg and Oak Grove and a low-cost veterinary clinic.

Shelter hours are noon to 5 p.m. Thursday through Tuesday. The shelter is closed Wednesdays.

Officials said those unable to adopt can support the effort through donations to assist with the care of animals awaiting homes.

item.title: Salvation Army to Host 1920s-Themed Senior Prom in Jackson - Darkhorse Press
item.author: Therese Apel
item.description:
JACKSON — Senior citizens in the Jackson area are invited to step back into the Roaring ’20s this weekend during a vintage-themed prom hosted by The Salvation Army.

Organizers say the afternoon celebration is designed specifically for older adults and will feature 1920s-inspired décor, music, light refreshments and dancing. Attendees are encouraged to wear vintage attire reflecting the era.

“Our seniors are a treasured part of our community,” said Major Timothy Delaney, commanding officer of The Salvation Army in Jackson. “This event is a wonderful opportunity to honor them, celebrate their stories, and provide a space filled with dignity, fun and fellowship.”

The Salvation Army said the event aims to offer a safe and welcoming environment where seniors can build friendships and create lasting memories.

For more information about the Senior Prom or other programs, call 601-982-4881.

item.title: Jones County crash suspect faces DUI charges; ICE detainer leads to transfer from detention facility - Darkhorse Press
item.author: Morgan Howard
item.description:
JONES COUNTY — A driver arrested in an overnight crash on U.S. Highway 29 North that damaged Dixie Electric Power Association equipment and left hundreds without electricity was later taken into federal custody after an immigration detainer was discovered in court.

The Jones County Sheriff’s Department said it assisted the Mississippi Highway Patrol at a crash scene near 1961 Highway 29 North at the intersection of Justin Adams Drive.

Deputy Lou Lowe arrived and took the driver, Richard Castillo, 30, into custody pending the arrival of state troopers, the sheriff’s department said. Authorities said neither Castillo nor a passenger in the vehicle was injured.

Dixie EPA infrastructure was damaged when a power pole was broken and power lines fell across the roadway, the sheriff’s department said. The outage affected hundreds of Dixie EPA members.

Troopers arrested Castillo and charged him with DUI first offense, no insurance and failure to keep lane, authorities said. He was booked into the Jones County Adult Detention Facility pending an initial appearance in Jones County Justice Court.

Dixie EPA linemen and support crews worked to repair the damage and restore service, according to the sheriff’s department. Jones County Fire District 1 volunteer units also responded and assisted with traffic control.

Authorities said an Immigration and Customs Enforcement detainer was discovered when Castillo appeared in Jones County court before Judge Grant Hedgepeth. The sheriff’s department said Castillo was later picked up by ICE at the Jones County Adult Detention Facility and released to federal custody.

item.description:
UPDATE: On Wednesday, Jamecia Harper appeared before a Municipal Court Judge and received a $50K bond for the charge of Convicted Felon with a Firearm, and no bond on the Murder charge.

Authorities have not released a possible motive in the case. It was not immediately clear whether Harper has an attorney or when she is expected to appear in court.

The shooting marked the city’s seventh homicide of the year, according to police.

GREENVILLE – A 6-year-old boy was injured Monday after he shot himself with a handgun, and his father has been arrested on a child neglect charge, according to Greenville police.

Officers responded about 5:40 p.m. Feb. 16 to Delta Health Systems at 1400 E. Union Avenue after a report of a juvenile with a gunshot wound, the Greenville Police Department said.

Police said they spoke with the child’s father, Justin Lowe Sr., who told officers his son shot himself with his 9mm handgun. The father told investigators he had gotten up to use the restroom when he heard a gunshot, then ran into the room and found his son had been shot in the leg.

The child was taken to the emergency room and was later transported to another medical facility for additional treatment. Police said the injury was considered non-life-threatening.

Investigators arrested Lowe on one count of child neglect. He is being held at the Washington County Regional Correctional Facility pending an initial court appearance.

All suspects are presumed innocent unless proven guilty.

item.title: Como Man Sentenced to 5 Years in Federal Prison for Cocaine Distribution - Darkhorse Press
item.author: Therese Apel
item.description:
ABERDEEN — A Como man was sentenced Tuesday to five years in federal prison after pleading guilty to distributing cocaine, federal officials announced.

Irish Lee, 49, was sentenced to 60 months in prison followed by three years of supervised release by Senior U.S. District Judge Michael P. Mills. Lee was remanded to the custody of the U.S. Marshals Service following the hearing.

According to court records, Lee previously pleaded guilty Nov. 13, 2025, to cocaine distribution. He was charged in a federal indictment that also named Christopher Mack as a co-defendant. Mack has also pleaded guilty to distribution of cocaine and is scheduled to be sentenced March 19.

U.S. Attorney Scott F. Leary and FBI Special Agent in Charge Robert Eikhoff announced the sentence.

Leary said the case is part of the Homeland Security Task Force initiative, a multiagency effort targeting drug trafficking, cartels and related crimes. The Mississippi task force includes agents from the FBI, Homeland Security Investigations, the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives and the Drug Enforcement Administration, working alongside the U.S. Attorney’s Office.

“Through historic interagency collaboration, the HSTF directs the full might of United States law enforcement towards identifying, investigating and prosecuting such crimes,” Leary said in a statement.

Eikhoff said illegal drugs such as cocaine harm communities and vowed continued enforcement efforts.

“The FBI, the Cleveland Police Department, the Homeland Security Task Force and our law enforcement partners will continue to work tirelessly to pursue individuals like Mr. Lee who bring these harmful substances into our communities,” Eikhoff said.

Assistant U.S. Attorney Chad Doleac prosecuted the case.

item.title: Tupelo police investigate shooting that injured juvenile on Fillmore Drive - Darkhorse Press
item.author: Morgan Howard
item.description:
Tupelo police are investigating a Friday night shooting that injured a juvenile in the 2100 block of Fillmore Drive.

Officers said they responded at about 10:13 p.m. Feb. 13 after the juvenile arrived at North Mississippi Medical Center by private vehicle with a gunshot wound.

According to a preliminary investigation, the juvenile had been attending a gathering at a home in the area when multiple shots were fired outside the residence.

Police said the victim was taken to the hospital before officers arrived and remains under medical care. Authorities said no additional medical details will be released.

Officers processed the residence and surrounding area for evidence, and detectives are continuing to investigate the circumstances of the shooting, police said.

No arrests have been made. Because a juvenile is involved, police said no additional identifying information will be released.

Anyone with information is asked to contact Tupelo police at 662-841-6491 or Crime Stoppers of Northeast Mississippi at 1-800-773-TIPS.

item.title: Saltillo man charged with felony marijuana trafficking, hydrocodone possession after Tupelo stop - Darkhorse Press
item.author: Morgan Howard
item.description:
TUPELO — A Saltillo man was arrested and charged with felony marijuana trafficking and felony possession of hydrocodone after a traffic stop in Tupelo and a follow-up search at a residence, according to the North Mississippi Narcotics Unit.

Agents said they stopped a 2022 Ford Bronco on Feb. 10 on North Gloster Street for an equipment violation and identified the driver as Octavious Nathaniel Coleman, 38, of Saltillo.

Investigators said probable cause was developed during the stop, and a vehicle search led to the seizure of about one pound of suspected marijuana and several dosage units of suspected hydrocodone.

After the stop, agents executed a search warrant at a residence on Mandi Drive in Saltillo, where they said they found more than 15 pounds of suspected marijuana, additional dosage units of suspected hydrocodone, two firearms and $76,970 in U.S. currency.

Coleman was charged with felony trafficking of marijuana and felony possession of hydrocodone.

Lee County Justice Court Judge Marilyn Reed denied bond because Coleman was already out on a felony bond on a previous charge at the time of his arrest, officials said.

Authorities said the investigation remains ongoing and additional charges may be filed.

item.title: Random Acts of Kindness Day Encourages Small Gestures With Big Impact - Darkhorse Press
item.author: Therese Apel
item.description:
A cup of coffee paid for in the drive-thru line. A handwritten note left on a coworker’s desk. A stranger offering to carry groceries.

Those simple moments are at the heart of Random Acts of Kindness Day, observed annually on Feb. 17, a day dedicated to encouraging people to intentionally spread compassion in their communities.

Founded in 1995 in Denver, Colorado, by the nonprofit Random Acts of Kindness Foundation, the observance has grown into an international movement promoting everyday generosity. The organization later expanded the celebration into Random Acts of Kindness Week, emphasizing that kindness should extend far beyond a single day.

“Make Kindness the Norm, Not the Exception,” the foundation urges on its website, highlighting the social and emotional benefits of thoughtful actions.

Research cited by the organization suggests kindness carries measurable health benefits. Acts of generosity can release hormones such as oxytocin and serotonin, which are associated with reduced stress and increased happiness. According to statistics shared by the foundation, people who regularly engage in kind behavior have 23% lower cortisol levels, and a 2020 survey found that 63% of adults reported improved mental health both from receiving and giving kindness.

Organizers say kindness also strengthens relationships in schools, workplaces and neighborhoods, helping build trust and empathy while breaking down social barriers.

The movement has attracted more than 261,000 self-described “RAKtivists” in 89 countries, according to RandomActsOfKindness.org . Participants receive a “Daily Dose of Kindness®” email with ideas and inspiration for incorporating compassion into everyday life.

While the observance is modern, advocates note that kindness itself is timeless. From community volunteers to global humanitarian figures, history has repeatedly shown how small actions can leave lasting impressions.

Supporters of the day say participation does not require money or grand gestures. Holding a door, offering encouragement, checking on a neighbor or simply listening can create a ripple effect.

Random Acts of Kindness Day serves as a reminder that meaningful change often begins with ordinary people choosing to act with care — one small gesture at a time.

item.title: Oxford-Lafayette Community Assistance Fund Launched to Aid Winter Storm Fern Recovery - Darkhorse Press
item.author: Therese Apel
item.description:
OXFORD — Community leaders, churches and nonprofit organizations in Oxford and Lafayette County have launched a coordinated relief effort to assist residents recovering from Winter Storm Fern.

The Oxford-Lafayette Community Assistance Fund was created as a collaborative response to provide financial assistance to individuals and families facing storm-related hardship. Organizers say the effort is designed to bridge the gap while residents wait for potential state or federal assistance.

Rather than establishing a single centralized donation site, participating churches and nonprofit partners are working through their own networks and channels to coordinate giving and distribute aid quickly where it is most needed.

Initial assistance will focus on urgent needs affecting safety and housing stability, including electrical repairs, plumbing repairs, tree removal and debris hazards. Organizers said additional categories of support may be added as needs are assessed and resources grow.

Residents of the city of Oxford or Lafayette County experiencing verified storm-related hardship may request assistance through a community intake process. Walk-up intake hours will be held from 9 a.m. to noon Feb. 18 through Feb. 28 at the Old OPC Building, located under the Blue Oxford Water tower at 310 S. 15th St.

Requests may also be submitted online at https://tinyurl.com/fernhelp or by calling 662-234-1100.

Applications will be reviewed by a collaborative assessment team led by Doors of Hope in partnership with the North Mississippi Exchange Family Center. The team will verify eligibility, prioritize urgent safety concerns and match approved cases with available resources. When possible, payments will be made directly to licensed vendors or service providers for verified repairs.

Participating church partners include Oxford-University United Methodist Church , First Baptist Church Oxford , First Presbyterian Church and St. Peter’s Episcopal Church . Community and nonprofit partners include Doors of Hope and the North Mississippi Exchange Family Center .

Organizers are also building a network of licensed local vendors to assist with recovery work, prioritizing electrical and plumbing repairs and tree removal. Community members may submit vendor information through an online form. Participation in the network does not guarantee work assignments but allows businesses to be considered as recovery needs arise.

Organizations interested in joining the coordinated fundraising effort may contact Chris McAlilly, lead pastor of Oxford-University United Methodist Church, at [email protected] .

Organizers said the goal of the fund is to help neighbors recover, rebuild and remain safely housed through a shared community response.

item.title: Nettleton Man Charged With Sexual Battery of Child Under 14 - Darkhorse Press
item.author: Therese Apel
item.description:
LEE COUNTY — A 25-year-old Nettleton man has been charged with two counts of sexual battery of a child under 14 following an investigation into alleged abuse involving a child younger than 6, Lee County Sheriff Jim Johnson said in a Facebook release Tuesday.

The Lee County Sheriff’s Office said it was notified by Child Protective Services of possible sexual abuse involving a young child. The agency’s Criminal Investigation Division launched an inquiry, during which allegations of sexual assault against a child surfaced.

Johnson alleged that Casey Drake Moore committed sexual acts against the child on at least two occasions in Lee County. Authorities also developed information suggesting a similar incident may have occurred in another jurisdiction and said they are sharing information with officials there to assist in a separate investigation.

Moore was arrested Feb. 13 and charged with two counts of sexual battery of a child under 14. A Lee County Justice Court judge set his bond at $500,000.

The investigation remains ongoing, and additional charges may be filed as new information becomes available.

The sheriff’s office expressed appreciation to Child Protective Services and the Easter Seals of Mississippi Child Advocacy Center for their assistance in the case.

item.title: Jackson State awarded $14.5 million NIH contract to extend Jackson Heart Study training center - Darkhorse Press
item.author: Morgan Howard
item.description:
JACKSON – Jackson State University has received a 10-year, $14.5 million federal contract to continue its Jackson Heart Study Graduate Training and Education Center, the university announced Tuesday.

The award comes from the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute and the National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities, both part of the National Institutes of Health. University officials said the funding renews Jackson State’s role in the long-running Jackson Heart Study collaboration, which they describe as the largest investigation of cardiovascular disease in African Americans.

Jackson State said it has received more than $25 million in NIH funding related to the study since 2013.

Interim President Denise Jones Gregory said the new award reflects the university’s ability to secure major federal research partnerships and support health outcomes for families.

Heart disease remains a leading cause of death in the United States, and African Americans face higher rates, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The university said related conditions, including hypertension, obesity and diabetes, also disproportionately affect Black communities and contribute to cardiovascular risk.

Launched in 1998, the Jackson Heart Study has followed more than 5,300 participants ages 34 to 85 in the Jackson metropolitan area, building long-term health data and biological samples used for research and prevention efforts. The program marked a 25-year milestone last year tied to its first participant clinical exam in 2000.

The Graduate Training and Education Center at Jackson State was established in 2013 to prepare graduate students for careers in biomedical and public health sciences, with an emphasis on disease prevention and health promotion in underserved communities.

Dr. Marinelle Payton, principal investigator of the center at Jackson State, said the renewed funding will help train future public health leaders to translate cardiovascular research into prevention strategies and earlier care.

Dr. Almesha Campbell, the university’s vice president for research and economic development, said the award strengthens Jackson State’s research role while expanding workforce development focused on health disparities.

Partner institutions in the Jackson Heart Study collaboration include the University of Mississippi Medical Center, Tougaloo College, the University of Southern Mississippi, Wake Forest University and the G.A. Carmichael Family Health Center.

(Written from a press release from The LEPR Agency)

item.title: Jackson police investigate fatal hit-and-run involving man in wheelchair on McDowell Road - Darkhorse Press
item.author: Morgan Howard
item.description:
JACKSON — A 31-year-old man was killed in a hit-and-run crash Monday night on East McDowell Road, according to the Jackson Police Department.

Police said officers were dispatched at about 8:41 p.m. to the 400 block of East McDowell Road, near 411 E. McDowell Road, after a report of a fatal vehicle-versus-pedestrian crash.

According to an accident investigator’s preliminary report, an unknown vehicle traveling east on McDowell Road struck a male pedestrian who was believed to be in a wheelchair in the middle of the street. Police said the driver did not remain at the scene.

The victim was pronounced dead, and his body was recovered by the coroner. His identity is being withheld pending notification of next of kin.

The crash remains under investigation. Anyone with information is asked to call Jackson police at 601-960-1234 or Crime Stoppers at 601-355-TIPS (8477).

item.title: Inmate dies after being found unresponsive in Alcorn County Jail cell - Darkhorse Press
item.author: Morgan Howard
item.description:
ALCORN COUNTY – An inmate at the Alcorn County Jail was found unresponsive early Tuesday during routine cell checks and was later pronounced dead, according to the Alcorn County Sheriff’s Office.

Sheriff’s officials said jail staff discovered the inmate at about 6:30 a.m. in a single-occupancy cell.

Staff began CPR immediately and called for medical assistance, authorities said. Magnolia EMS responded and pronounced the inmate dead at the jail.

Alcorn County deputies and investigators secured the scene, and the Mississippi Bureau of Investigation was called to conduct an independent investigation, the sheriff’s office said.

The Alcorn County coroner is expected to transport the body to the state crime lab for an autopsy. Authorities said additional information will be released when available.
